reviewText: I was intrigued with the subject matter.  It opens up a new or maybe old view that children can be killers without remorse.  After all, humans have a measure of good and evil, and it's our choice or should I say "our WILL" to choice which road to take.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Joey Pollari and Gabriele Angieri are superb actors, truly talented and made the movie worth watching.The story line, though unique in the serial killer genre, leaves much to be desired as it seems to lead to the moral that not everything can be profiled - or can it?  Yes, the question is the moral.The female FBI agent seems to infer that heartless is only a matter of which side of the law one is on.  Her character is unsympathetic - which may be the point - and uninterested in peoples reasons, feelings and lives.  Not unlike the serial killer, both are intent on the "bottom line". Either that or her acting is not great.  I give the movie credit for trying - but I could be way wrong here.Anyway, it's an odd story that left me wondering if I missed something entirely - like a book with a chapter torn out.  The potential of the story kept me watching, yet left me perturbed that it did when nothing really panned out.5 Stars for the 2 main actors, 1 for the story which started well then sunk in the frozen lake somewhere sending up a poof of the universal question, "Who am I?"  By that time, I didn't care.
summary: Torn between the acting and the story.

reviewText: We're all used to adult serial killers in movies.  You see a lot more men in these roles than women.  Actually, I don't recall a female in this type of role, but that obviously doesn't mean it hasn't happened.  This movie adds an extra twist of suspense and horror that the monster is a child who seemed to have a normal childhood.
summary: How could a child be so evil and smart ! ! !
